bug.author: femust

comments.comment: Hi <denchmark-link:https://github.com/femust>@femust</denchmark-link> , can you compile open3d in Debug mode to get more information?
Yes, I saw your previous post and I compiled in debug mode as well, BUT I had the same information, so successfully loaded, but when visualizing seg fault

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/benjaminum>@benjaminum</denchmark-link> funny enough is that the visualization works when I use python (installed via pip install ), but when I use cpp then seg fault

@benjaminum funny enough is that the visualization works when I use python (installed via pip install ), but when I use cpp then seg fault
Just to get an overview of the configurations:
Visualization fails when compiling from source and creating a C++ binary linking open3d. Visualization works when installing the package from PyPI
Is this correct? Does the visualization work with the python package compiled from source? (make install-pip-package) Can you get more information about the segfault with a debugger? If you have gdb the following will print some parts of the stack <denchmark-code>gdb -ex run -ex bt -ex li -ex up -ex li -ex up -ex li -ex up -ex li -ex quit ./binary_that_causes_segfault </denchmark-code>

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/femust>@femust</denchmark-link> Can you check if you have compiled open3d in Debug mode (can be enabled during configure with ) This could help to better pinpoint the instruction that is failing.

it looks a bit like openGL problem...
Yes, looks like a problem with opengl. Can you also provide the information from glxinfo and the libraries you link to with ldd your_binary?

so python file doesn't link opengl at all ? (not sure whether this libGL is connected somehow with opengl?)

No, the python file itself does not link anything. The C modules imported in the python file will load libraries. open3d_pybind.cpython-36m-x86_64-linux-gnu.so is such a C module. Thanks for the information. The paths to the GL libs are the same for the binary and the C module, which means there isn't a problem with using different OpenGL implementations. However, the binary links libOpenGL.so and libGL.so while the C module just links libGL.so. I am not sure if it is OK to link both as they probably implement almost the same functions. I have to do some research on this.
